After the retirement of Sandberg and the trade of Dunston, the Cubs had holes to fill and the signing of Henry Rodríguez, known affectionately as "H-Rod" to bat cleanup provided protection for Sammy Sosa in the lineup, as Rodriguez slugged 31 round-trippers in his first season in Chicago. Kevin Tapani led the club with a career high 19 wins, Rod Beck anchored a strong bullpen and Mark Grace turned in one of his best seasons. The Cubs were swamped by media attention in 1998, and the team's two biggest headliners were Sosa and rookie flamethrower Kerry Wood. Wood's signature performance was one-hitting the Houston Astros, a game in which he tied the major league record of 20 strikeouts in nine innings. His torrid strikeout numbers earned Wood the nickname "Kid K," and ultimately earned him the 1998 NL Rookie of the Year award. Sosa caught fire in June, hitting a major league record 20 home runs in the month, and his home run race with Cardinals slugger Mark McGwire transformed the pair into international superstars in a matter of weeks. McGwire finished the season with a new major league record of 70 home runs, but Sosa's .308 average and 66 homers earned him the National League MVP Award. After a down-to-the-wire Wild Card chase with the San Francisco Giants, Chicago and San Francisco ended the regular season tied, and thus squared off in a one-game playoff at Wrigley Field in which third baseman Gary Gaetti hit the eventual game winning homer. The win propelled the Cubs into the postseason once again with a 90–73 regular season tally. Unfortunately, the bats went cold in October, as manager Jim Riggleman's club batted .183 and scored only four runs en route to being swept by Atlanta. A true predator can commonly be known as one that kills and eats another living thing. Whereas other types of predator all harm their prey in some way, this form kills them. Predators may hunt actively for prey in pursuit predation, or sit and wait for prey to approach within striking distance, as in ambush predators. Some predators kill large prey and dismember or chew it prior to eating it, such as a jaguar or a human; others may eat their (usually much smaller) prey whole, as does a bottlenose dolphin swallowing a fish, or a snake, duck or stork swallowing a frog. Some animals that kill both large and small prey for their size (domestic cats and dogs are prime examples) may do either depending upon the circumstances; either would devour a large insect whole but dismember a rabbit. Some predation entails venom that subdues a prey creature before the predator ingests the prey by killing, which the box jellyfish does, or disabling it, found in the behavior of the cone shell. In some cases, the venom, as in rattlesnakes and some spiders, contributes to the digestion of the prey item even before the predator begins eating. In other cases, the prey organism may die in the mouth

In 680 Ibn al-Zubayr fled Medina for Mecca. Hearing about Husayn's opposition to Yazid I, the people of Kufa sent to Husayn asking him to take over with their support. Al-Husayn sent his cousin Muslim bin Agail to verify if they would rally behind him. When the news reached Yazid I, he sent Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad, ruler of Basrah, with the instruction to prevent the people of Kufa rallying behind Al-Husayn. Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad managed to disperse the crowd that gathered around Muslim bin Agail and captured him. Realizing Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad had been instructed to prevent Husayn from establishing support in Kufa, Muslim bin Agail requested a message to be sent to Husayn to prevent his immigration to Kufa. The request was denied and Ubayd-Allah bin Ziyad killed Muslim bin Agail. While Ibn al-Zubayr would stay in Mecca until his death, Husayn decided to travel on to Kufa with his family, unaware of the lack of support there. Husayn and his family were intercepted by Yazid I's forces led by Amru bin Saad, Shamar bin Thi Al-Joshan, and Hussain bin Tamim, who fought Al-Husayn and his male family members until they were killed. The Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo, signed on February 2, 1848, by American diplomat Nicholas Trist and Mexican plenipotentiary representatives Luis G. Cuevas, Bernardo Couto, and Miguel Atristain, ended the war, gave the U.S. undisputed control of Texas, and established the U.S.–Mexican border of the Rio Grande. As news of peace negotiations reached the state, new call to arms began to flare among the people of the state. But as the Mexican officials in Chihuahua heard that General Price was heading back to Mexico with a large force comprising several companies of infantry and three companies of cavalry and one division of light artillery from Santa Fe on February 8, 1848, Ángel Trías sent a message to Sacramento Pass to ask for succession of the area as they understood the war had concluded. General Price, misunderstanding this as a deception by the Mexican forces, continued to advance towards the state capital. On March 16, 1848 Price began negotiations with Ángel Trías, but the Mexican leader responded with an ultimatum to General Price. On the other hand, the lack of an effective royal justice system in the Kingdom led to the social conflict known as the Guerras Irmandiñas ('Wars of the brotherhoods'), when leagues of peasants and burghers, with the support of a number of knights, noblemen, and under legal protection offered by the remote king, toppled many of the castles of the Kingdom and briefly drove the noblemen into Portugal and Castile. Soon after, in the late 15th century, in the dynastic conflict between Isabella I of Castile and Joanna La Beltraneja, part of the Galician aristocracy supported Joanna. After Isabella's victory, she initiated an administrative and political reform which the chronicler Jeronimo Zurita defined as "doma del Reino de Galicia": 'It was then when the taming of Galicia began, because not just the local lords and knights, but all the people of that nation were the ones against the others very bold and warlike'. These reforms, while establishing a local government and tribunal (the Real Audiencia del Reino de Galicia) and bringing the nobleman under submission, also brought most Galician monasteries and institutions under Castilian control, in what has been criticized as a process of centralisation. Terry Eastland, the author who wrote From Ending Affirmative Action: The Case for Colorblind Justice states, "Most arguments for affirmative action fall into two categories: remedying past discrimination and promoting diversity". Eastland believes that the founders of affirmative action did not anticipate how the benefits of affirmative action would go to those who did not need it, mostly middle class minorities. Additionally, she argues that affirmative action carries with it a stigma that can create feelings of self-doubt and entitlement in minorities. Eastland believes that affirmative action is a great risk that only sometimes pays off, and that without it we would be able to compete more freely with one another. The Royal Assent ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the House of Commons. On the day of the event, the Speaker of the Senate will read to the chamber a notice from the secretary to the governor general indicating when the viceroy or a deputy thereof will arrive. The Senate thereafter cannot adjourn until after the ceremony. The speaker moves to sit beside the throne, the Mace Bearer, with mace in hand, stands adjacent to him or her, and the governor general enters to take the speaker's chair. The Usher of the Black Rod is then commanded by the speaker to summon the Members of Parliament, who follow Black Rod back to the Senate, the Sergeant-at-Arms carrying the mace of the House of Commons. In the Senate, those from the commons stand behind the bar, while Black Rod proceeds to stand next to the governor general, who then nods his or her head to signify Royal Assent to the presented bills (which do not include appropriations bills). Once the list of bills is complete, the Clerk of the Senate states: "in Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy] doth assent to these bills." If there are any appropriation bills to receive Royal Assent, the Speaker of the House of Commons will read their titles and the Senate clerk repeats them to the governor general, who nods his or her head to communicate Royal Assent. The early and mid-1980s saw economic trouble for Libya; from 1982 to 1986, the country's annual oil revenues dropped from $21 billion to $5.4 billion. Focusing on irrigation projects, 1983 saw construction start on "Gaddafi's Pet Project", the Great Man-Made River; although designed to be finished by the end of the decade, it remained incomplete at the start of the 21st century. Military spending increased, while other administrative budgets were cut back. Libya had long supported the FROLINAT militia in neighbouring Chad, and in December 1980, re-invaded Chad at the request of the Frolinat-controlled GUNT government to aid in the civil war; in January 1981, Gaddafi suggested a political merger. The Organisation of African Unity (OAU) rejected this, and called for a Libyan withdrawal, which came about in November 1981. The civil war resumed, and so Libya sent troops back in, clashing with French forces who supported the southern Chadian forces. Many African nations had tired of Libya's policies of interference in foreign affairs; by 1980, nine African states had cut off diplomatic relations with Libya, while in 1982 the OAU cancelled its scheduled conference in Tripoli in order to prevent Gaddafi gaining chairmanship. PAL discs could carry one pair of audio tracks, either analog or digital and the digital tracks on a PAL disc were 16-bit 44.1 kHz as on a CD; in the UK, the term "LaserVision" is used to refer to discs with analog sound, while "LaserDisc" is used for those with digital audio. The digital sound signal in both formats are EFM-encoded as in CD. Dolby Digital (also called AC-3) and DTS—which are now common on DVD titles—first became available on LaserDisc, and Star Wars: Episode I – The Phantom Menace (1999) which was released on LaserDisc in Japan, is among the first home video releases ever to include 6.1 channel Dolby Digital EX Surround. Unlike DVDs, which carry Dolby Digital audio in digital form, LaserDiscs store Dolby Digital in a frequency modulated form within a track normally used for analog audio. Extracting Dolby Digital from a LaserDisc required a player equipped with a special "AC-3 RF" output and an external demodulator in addition to an AC-3 decoder. From his diagrams of a small number of particles interacting in spacetime, Feynman could then model all of physics in terms of the spins of those particles and the range of coupling of the fundamental forces. Feynman attempted an explanation of the strong interactions governing nucleons scattering called the parton model. The parton model emerged as a complement to the quark model developed by his Caltech colleague Murray Gell-Mann. The relationship between the two models was murky; Gell-Mann referred to Feynman's partons derisively as "put-ons". In the mid-1960s, physicists believed that quarks were just a bookkeeping device for symmetry numbers, not real particles, as the statistics of the Omega-minus particle, if it were interpreted as three identical strange quarks bound together, seemed impossible if quarks were real. The Stanford linear accelerator deep inelastic scattering experiments of the late 1960s showed, analogously to Ernest Rutherford's experiment of scattering alpha particles on gold nuclei in 1911, that nucleons (protons and neutrons) contained point-like particles that scattered electrons. It was natural to identify these with quarks, but Feynman's parton model attempted to interpret the experimental data in a way that did not introduce additional hypotheses. For example, the data showed that some 45% of the energy momentum was carried by electrically-neutral particles in the nucleon. These electrically-neutral particles are now seen to be the gluons that carry the forces between the quarks and carry also the three-valued color quantum number that solves the Omega-minus problem. In late 1203, John attempted to relieve Château Gaillard, which although besieged by Philip was guarding the eastern flank of Normandy. John attempted a synchronised operation involving land-based and water-borne forces, considered by most historians today to have been imaginative in conception, but overly complex for forces of the period to have carried out successfully. John's relief operation was blocked by Philip's forces, and John turned back to Brittany in an attempt to draw Philip away from eastern Normandy. John successfully devastated much of Brittany, but did not deflect Philip's main thrust into the east of Normandy. Opinions vary amongst historians as to the military skill shown by John during this campaign, with most recent historians arguing that his performance was passable, although not impressive.[nb 8] John's situation began to deteriorate rapidly. The eastern border region of Normandy had been extensively cultivated by Philip and his predecessors for several years, whilst Angevin authority in the south had been undermined by Richard's giving away of various key castles some years before. His use of routier mercenaries in the central regions had rapidly eaten away his remaining support in this area too, which set the stage for a sudden collapse of Angevin power.[nb 9] John retreated back across the Channel in December, sending orders for the establishment of a fresh defensive line to the west of Chateau Gaillard. In March 1204, Gaillard fell. John's mother Eleanor died the following month. This was not just a personal blow for

In 2013, however, a study of Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA by a team led by Martin B. Richards of the University of Huddersfield in England reached different conclusions, again corroborating the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. Testing was performed on the full 16,600 DNA units composing mitochondrial DNA (the 2006 Behar study had only tested 1,000 units) in all their subjects, and the study found that the four main female Ashkenazi founders had descent lines that were established in Europe 10,000 to 20,000 years in the past while most of the remaining minor founders also have a deep European ancestry. The study states that the great majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages were not brought from the Near East (i.e., they were non-Israelite), nor were they recruited in the Caucasus (i.e., they were non-Khazar), but instead they were assimilated within Europe, primarily of Italian and Old French origins. Richards summarized the findings on the female line as such: "[N]one [of the mtDNA] came from the North Caucasus, located along the border between Europe and Asia between the Black and Caspian seas. All of our presently available studies including my own, should thoroughly debunk one of the most questionable, but still tenacious, hypotheses: that most Ashkenazi Jews can trace their roots to the mysterious Khazar Kingdom that flourished during the ninth century in the region between the Byzantine Empire and the Persian Empire." At the 1912 Salon d'Automne an architectural installation was exhibited that quickly became known as Maison Cubiste (Cubist House), signed Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare along with a group of collaborators. Metzinger and Gleizes in Du "Cubisme", written during the assemblage of the "Maison Cubiste", wrote about the autonomous nature of art, stressing the point that decorative considerations should not govern the spirit of art. Decorative work, to them, was the "antithesis of the picture". "The true picture" wrote Metzinger and Gleizes, "bears its raison d'être within itself. It can be moved from a church to a drawing-room, from a museum to a study. Essentially independent, necessarily complete, it need not immediately satisfy the mind: on the contrary, it should lead it, little by little, towards the fictitious depths in which the coordinative light resides. It does not harmonize with this or that ensemble; it harmonizes with things in general, with the universe: it is an organism...". "Mare's ensembles were accepted as frames for Cubist works because they allowed paintings and sculptures their independence", writes Christopher Green, "creating a play of contrasts, hence the involvement not only of Gleizes and Metzinger themselves, but of Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (Raymond Duchamp-Villon designed the facade) and Mare's old friends Léger and Roger La Fresnaye". Some rock musicians today use mandolins, often single-stringed electric models rather than double-stringed acoustic mandolins. One example is Tim Brennan of the Irish-American punk rock band Dropkick Murphys. In addition to electric guitar, bass, and drums, the band uses several instruments associated with traditional Celtic music, including mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes. The band explains that these instruments accentuate the growling sound they favor. The 1991 R.E.M. hit "Losing My Religion" was driven by a few simple mandolin licks played by guitarist Peter Buck, who also played the mandolin in nearly a dozen other songs. The single peaked at No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 chart (#1 on the rock and alternative charts), Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes has made frequent use of the mandolin, most notably on the Black Crowes song "Locust Street." Armenian American rock group System of A Down makes extensive use of the mandolin on their 2005 double album Mezmerize/Hypnotize. Pop punk band Green Day has used a mandolin in several occasions, especially on their 2000 album, Warning. Boyd Tinsley, violin player of the Dave Matthews Band has been using an electric mandolin since 2005. Frontman Colin Meloy and guitarist Chris Funk of The Decemberists regularly employ the mandolin in the band's music. Nancy Wilson, rhythm guitarist of Heart, uses a mandolin in Heart's song "Dream of the Archer" from the album Little Queen,

President Truman, symbolizing a broad-based desire for an Eisenhower candidacy for president, again in 1951 pressed him to run for the office as a Democrat. It was at this time that Eisenhower voiced his disagreements with the Democratic party and declared himself and his family to be Republicans. A "Draft Eisenhower" movement in the Republican Party persuaded him to declare his candidacy in the 1952 presidential election to counter the candidacy of non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. The effort was a long struggle; Eisenhower had to be convinced that political circumstances had created a genuine duty for him to offer himself as a candidate, and that there was a mandate from the populace for him to be their President. Henry Cabot Lodge, who served as his campaign manager, and others succeeded in convincing him, and in June 1952 he resigned his command at NATO to campaign full-time. Eisenhower defeated Taft for the nomination, having won critical delegate votes from Texas. Eisenhower's campaign was noted for the simple but effective slogan, "I Like Ike". In 2006, Morgan Stanley purchased 20 acres (8.1 ha) directly north of the Showboat Atlantic City Hotel and Casino for a new $2 billion plus casino resort. Revel Entertainment Group was named as the project's developer for the Revel Casino. Revel was hindered with many problems, with the biggest setback to the company being in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, the owner of 90% of Revel Entertainment Group, decided to discontinue funding for continued construction and put its stake in Revel up for sale. Early in 2010 the New Jersey state legislature passed a bill offering tax incentives to attract new investors and complete the job, but a poll by Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind released in March 2010 showed that three of five voters (60%) opposed the legislation, and two of three of those who opposed it "strongly" opposed it. Ultimately, Governor Chris Christie offered Revel $261 million in state tax credits to assist the casino once it opened. As of March 2011[update], Revel had completed all of the exterior work and had continued work on the interior after finally receiving the funding necessary to complete construction. It had a soft opening in April 2012, and was fully open by May 2012. Ten months later, in February 2013, after serious losses and a write-down in the value of the resort from $2.4 billion to $450 million, Revel filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The final major aspect of identity formation is self-esteem. Self-esteem is defined as one's thoughts and feelings about one's self-concept and identity. Most theories on self-esteem state that there is a grand desire, across all genders and ages, to maintain, protect and enhance their self-esteem. Contrary to popular belief, there is no empirical evidence for a significant drop in self-esteem over the course of adolescence. "Barometric self-esteem" fluctuates rapidly and can cause severe distress and anxiety, but baseline self-esteem remains highly stable across adolescence. The validity of global self-esteem scales has been questioned, and many suggest that more specific scales might reveal more about the adolescent experience. Girls are most likely to enjoy high self-esteem when engaged in supportive relationships with friends, the most important function of friendship to them is having someone who can provide social and moral support. When they fail to win friends' approval or couldn't find someone with whom to share common activities and common interests, in these cases, girls suffer from low self-esteem. In contrast, boys are more concerned with establishing and asserting their independence and defining their relation to authority. For its complete North American release, the Nintendo Entertainment System was progressively released over the ensuing years in four different bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the Action Set and the Power Set. The Deluxe Set, retailing at US$199.99 (equivalent to $475 in 2016), included R.O.B., a light gun called the NES Zapper, two controllers, and two Game Paks: Gyromite, and Duck Hunt. The Basic Set, retailing at US$89.99 with no game, and US$99.99 bundled with "Super Mario Bros." The Action Set, retailing in 1988 for US$149.99, came with the Control Deck, two game controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual Game Pak containing both Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt. In 1989, the Power Set included the console, two game controllers, a NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple Game Pak containing Super Mario Bros, Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet. In 1990, a Sports Set bundle was released, including the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless multitap adapter, four game controllers, and a dual Game Pak containing Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup. Two more bundle packages were later released using the original model NES console. The Challenge Set of 1992 included the console, two controllers, and a Super Mario Bros. 3 Game Pak for a retail price of US$89.99. A period of division for the Liberals followed, with former Treasurer John Howard competing with former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock for supremacy. The Australian economy was facing the early 1990s recession. Unemployment reached 11.4% in 1992. Under Dr John Hewson, in November 1991, the opposition launched the 650-page Fightback! policy document − a radical collection of "dry", economic liberal measures including the introduction of a Goods and Services Tax (GST), various changes to Medicare including the abolition of bulk billing for non-concession holders, the introduction of a nine-month limit on unemployment benefits, various changes to industrial relations including the abolition of awards, a $13 billion personal income tax cut directed at middle and upper income earners, $10 billion in government spending cuts, the abolition of state payroll taxes and the privatisation of a large number of government owned enterprises − representing the start of a very different future direction to the keynesian economic conservatism practiced by previous Liberal/National Coalition governments. The 15 percent GST was the centerpiece of the policy document. Through 1992, Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating mounted a campaign against the Fightback package, and particularly against the GST, which he described as an attack on the working class in that it shifted the tax burden from direct taxation of the wealthy to indirect taxation as a broad-based consumption tax. Pressure group activity and public opinion was relentless, which led Hewson to exempt food from the proposed GST − leading to questions surrounding the complexity of what food was and wasn't to be exempt from the GST. The Montana Territory was formed on April 26, 1864, when the U.S. passed the Organic Act. Schools started forming in the area before it was officially a territory as families started settling into the area. The first schools were subscription schools that typically held in the teacher's home. The first formal school on record was at Fort Owen in Bitterroot valley in 1862. The students were Indian children and the children of Fort Owen employees. The first school term started in early winter and only lasted until February 28. Classes were taught by Mr. Robinson. Another early subscription school was started by Thomas Dimsdale in Virginia City in 1863. In this school students were charged $1.75 per week. The Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly had its inaugural meeting in 1864. The first legislature authorized counties to levy taxes for schools, which set the foundations for public schooling. Madison County was the first to take advantage of the newly authorized taxes and it formed fhe first public school in Virginia City in 1886. The first school year was scheduled to begin in January 1866, but severe weather postponed its opening until March. The first school year ran through the summer and didn't end until August 17. One of the first teachers at the school was Sarah Raymond. She was a 25-year-old woman who had traveled to Virginia City via wagon train in 1865. To become a certified teacher, Raymond took a test in her home and paid a $6 fee in gold dust to obtain a teaching certificate. On 20 June 1794, Burke received a vote of thanks from the Commons for his services in the Hastings Trial and he immediately resigned his seat, being replaced by his son Richard. A tragic blow fell upon Burke with the loss of Richard in August 1794, to whom he was tenderly attached, and in whom he saw signs of promise, which were not patent to others and which, in fact, appear to have been non-existent (though this view may have rather reflected the fact that Richard Burke had worked successfully in the early battle for Catholic emancipation). King George III, whose favour he had gained by his attitude on the French Revolution, wished to create him Earl of Beaconsfield, but the death of his son deprived the opportunity of such an honour and all its attractions, so the only award he would accept was a pension of £2,500. Even this modest reward was attacked by the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale, to whom Burke replied in his Letter to a Noble Lord (1796): "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform". He argued that he was rewarded on merit, but the Duke of Bedford received his rewards from inheritance

The nation almost immediately fell into civil war that involved various factions fighting one another; these factions were often distinguished by clan loyalties. More than 500,000 residents fled during this time because of persecution, increased poverty and better economic opportunities in the West or in other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon came to power in 1992, defeating former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the vote. The elections took place shortly after the end of the war, and Tajikistan was in a state of complete devastation. The estimated dead numbered over 100,000. Around 1.2 million people were refugees inside and outside of the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was reached between Rahmon and opposition parties under the guidance of Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, a result widely praised as a successful United Nations peace keeping initiative. The ceasefire guaranteed 30% of ministerial positions would go to the opposition. Elections were held in 1999, though they were criticized by opposition parties and foreign observers as unfair and Rahmon was re-elected with 98% of the vote. Elections in 2006 were again won by Rahmon (with 79% of the vote) and he began his third term in office. Several opposition parties boycotted the 2006 election and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) criticized it, although observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States claimed the elections were legal and transparent. Rahmon's administration came under further criticism from the OSCE in October 2010 for its censorship and repression

Yale President Richard Levin attributes the run to Yale’s focus on creating "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional priority that began during the tenure of Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. The last major building work took place during the reign of King George V when, in 1913, Sir Aston Webb redesigned Blore's 1850 East Front to resemble in part Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. This new, refaced principal façade (of Portland stone) was designed to be the backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a large memorial statue of Queen Victoria, placed outside the main gates. George V, who had succeeded Edward VII in 1910, had a more serious personality than his father; greater emphasis was now placed on official entertaining and royal duties than on lavish parties. He arranged a series of command performances featuring jazz musicians such as the Original Dixieland Jazz Band (1919) – the first jazz performance for a head of state, Sidney Bechet, and Louis Armstrong (1932), which earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival as one of the venues making the greatest contribution to jazz music in the United Kingdom. George V's wife Queen Mary was a connoisseur of the arts, and took a keen interest in the Royal Collection of furniture and art, both restoring and adding to it. Queen Mary also had many new fixtures and fittings installed, such as the pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy, dating from 1810, which the Queen had installed in the ground floor Bow Room, the

The departures of Núñez and van Gaal were hardly noticed by the fans when compared to that of Luís Figo, then club vice-captain. Figo had become a cult hero, and was considered by Catalans to be one of their own. However, Barcelona fans were distraught by Figo's decision to join arch-rivals Real Madrid, and, during subsequent visits to the Camp Nou, Figo was given an extremely hostile reception. Upon his first return, a piglet's head and a full bottle of whiskey were thrown at him from the crowd. The next three years saw the club in decline, and managers came and went. van Gaal was replaced by Llorenç Serra Ferrer who, despite an extensive investment in players in the summer of 2000, presided over a mediocre league campaign and a humiliating first-round Champions League exit, and was eventually dismissed late in the season. Long-serving coach Carles Rexach was appointed as his replacement, initially on a temporary basis, and managed to at least steer the club to the last Champions League spot on the final day of the season. Despite better form in La Liga and a good run to the semi-finals of the Champions League, Rexach was never viewed as a long-term solution and that summer Louis van Gaal returned to the club for a second spell as manager. What followed, despite another decent Champions League performance, was one of the worst La Liga campaigns in the club's history, with the team as low as 15th in February 2003. This led to van Gaal's resignation and replacement for the rest of the campaign
sampled: In 1954, prominent Serbian and Croatian authors, linguists, and literary critics, supported by Matica srpska and Matica hrvatska, signed the Novi Sad Agreement. The first conclusion of this agreement declared: "Serbs, Croats, and Montenegrins share a single language with two equal variants, which have evolved around Zagreb (western) and Belgrade (eastern)." The agreement emphasized the equal status of the Cyrillic and Latin scripts, as well as the Ekavian and Ijekavian pronunciations. It also stipulated that the language should be officially called Serbo-Croatian, while the traditional names Serbian and Croatian could be used informally. Matica hrvatska and Matica srpska were tasked with collaborating on a dictionary, and a committee of Serbian and Croatian linguists was appointed to develop a pravopis. During the 1960s, both books were published simultaneously in Ijekavian Latin in Zagreb and Ekavian Cyrillic in Novi Sad. However, Croatian linguists argue that this was a unification attempt. The evidence for this claim is weak: Croatian linguist Stjepan Babić noted that Belgrade's television broadcasts consistently used the Latin script—this was accurate, yet not indicative of inequality, but rather due to usage frequency and prestige. Babić also objected that the Novi Sad Dictionary (1967) included words from both Croatian and Serbian variants side by side, which can be seen as an effort to honor both dialects, not promote unification. Additionally, Croatian linguists criticized supposedly unitarian segments of the Dictionary written by their own experts. They also overlooked that the Pravopisni rječnik's material originated from the Croatian Philological Society. Despite these points, Croatian intellectuals issued the Declaration on the Status and Name of the Croatian Literary Language in 1967. On its 45th anniversary in 2012, the Croatian weekly journal Forum republished the Declaration along with a critical analysis.

The Bush administration shifted its focus to Iraq, asserting that the removal of Saddam Hussein had become an urgent necessity. The reasons given included Saddam's attempts to acquire nuclear materials and his failure to account for biological and chemical weapons previously in his possession. These actions would breach U.N. sanctions regarding weapons of mass destruction (WMD). Despite the Bush administration’s strong claims about the presence of WMDs, key global powers like China, France, Germany, and Russia remained unconvinced of Iraq's threat, thus blocking a UN Security Council resolution endorsing force. In November 2002, Iraq allowed UN weapon inspectors, but while they were investigating the WMD claims, the Bush administration chose to wage war without UN consent, instructing the inspectors to withdraw. On March 20, 2003, the United States, along with a "coalition of the willing" including the United Kingdom, and to a lesser extent, Australia and Poland, invaded Iraq. Within three weeks, the invasion dismantled the Iraqi government and military, yet no WMDs were discovered. Some remnants of former materials and labs were found, but no definitive evidence. Nonetheless, on May 1, George W. Bush landed on the USS Abraham Lincoln and delivered a speech declaring the end of "major combat operations" in Iraq. At this time, Bush enjoyed a 66% approval rating according to a CNN–USA Today–Gallup poll. However, his popularity waned. Initially, the war was supported in the U.S., but as reconstruction efforts faced setbacks and casualty numbers rose, public support declined. Furthermore, the absence of expected WMD stockpiles led to significant debate over the justification for the war.

An adolescent's surroundings significantly influence their identity formation. Most studies focus on white, middle-class children, revealing that those with more privileged backgrounds tend to develop their identities more successfully. This stage of identity formation is vital in an adolescent's life. Recent findings indicate that the transition to adulthood now spans more years than it did in the mid-20th century. Consequently, the phase of youth, covering late adolescence to early adulthood, is increasingly recognized as a distinct life stage. This shift highlights the importance of various factors in identity development. Numerous elements like commitment, coping mechanisms, and social media shape an adolescent's social identity, all influenced by their environment. Children from privileged backgrounds encounter more opportunities and favorable situations. In contrast, adolescents from inner cities or crime-prone neighborhoods are more likely to face environments that could hinder their development. Adolescence is a critical period, and harmful exposures during this time can significantly impact future choices. Children in suburban areas, less exposed to negative influences, are more likely to engage in activities that enhance their identity development and lead to more successful outcomes.

The NFL preseason is notably more structured compared to other team sports. Each NFL team plays four preseason exhibition games annually, consisting of two home and two away games, except for two teams that participate in a fifth game, the Pro Football Hall of Fame Game. These games, primarily held in August, assist coaches in reducing the roster from 90 to 53 players for the regular season. While the preseason schedule isn't as fixed as the regular season, there are several limitations and traditions influencing opponent choices and game timings. Unlike baseball and hockey, split-squad games, where a team divides into two for multiple games on the same day, are not allowed. The NFL has hosted exhibition games in Europe, Japan, Canada, Australia, and Mexico to boost its popularity globally, though a proposed game in China was canceled due to financial and logistical issues. Playing against non-league opponents is generally prohibited, with the last such game occurring in 1972, and the final match against a non-NFL team (the all-NFL rookie College All-Stars) in 1976. Many fans dislike exhibition games, as they must pay regular-season prices for them as part of season-ticket packages, leading to numerous unsuccessful lawsuits against the NFL. The Pro Bowl, typically held after the NFL season but since 2011 played the week before the Super Bowl, is also classified as an exhibition game.

In practice, not every rule violation leads to a disqualification, as referees can use their discretion and aren't required to stop a match. Typically, immediate disqualifications by the referee occur with offenses like low blows, using weapons, interference, or attacking the referee. In WWE, a disqualification can only be decided if the referee personally witnesses the infraction; video evidence usually isn't sufficient. The referee's decision is generally final, although "Dusty finishes," named after Dusty Rhodes, can lead to a decision being overturned. It's not unusual for referees to be knocked out during a match, an event known as a "ref bump." While the referee is "unconscious," wrestlers can break the rules until the referee recovers or is replaced. Occasionally, a referee might disqualify a wrestler if they assume that wrestler caused the knockout; most referee knockouts are orchestrated to give a wrestler, often a villain, an advantage. For instance, a wrestler might collide with a referee at a slow speed, temporarily incapacitating the ref. During this time, a wrestler might pin their opponent for the win, except the referee is down. Sometimes a second referee runs in from backstage to count, but by then, the opponent may have had time to kick out.

In the 15th century, a dome was added and the naves were extended behind the choir, connecting the building to the tower and creating a main entrance. Archbishop Luis Alfonso de los Cameros initiated the construction of the main chapel in 1674, adorning the walls with Baroque-style marbles and bronzes of that era. At the start of the 18th century, German architect Conrad Rudolphus designed the façade of the main entrance. The other two doors lead into the transept: one is the Apostles’ Door in pure pointed Gothic from the 14th century, and the other is the Paláu Door. Extensions at the back of the cathedral reduce its apparent height. The 18th-century restoration rounded the pointed arches, replaced Gothic columns with Corinthian pillars, and redecorated the walls. The dome lacks a lantern, with its simple ceiling featuring two large side windows. There are four chapels on each side, in addition to those at the end and those opening into the choir, transept, and sanctuary, displaying numerous works by renowned artists. A silver reredos behind the altar was taken during the 1808 war and melted down to fund the campaign. The San Francesco chapel houses two paintings by Francisco Goya. Behind the Chapel of the Blessed Sacrament is a small Renaissance chapel built by Calixtus III. Next to the cathedral is a chapel dedicated to Our Lady of the Forsaken (Virgen de los Desamparados or Mare de Déu dels Desamparats).

Initial reviews of American Idol were varied. Ken Tucker from Entertainment Weekly described the show as "crazily entertaining" as television but "inconsequential" as music. Conversely, some critics praised the series for uncovering real talent. The show was also labeled a "sadistic musical bake-off" and "a romp in humiliation." Additional criticism focused on its product placement and perceived commercial intentions. Karla Peterson from The San Diego Union-Tribune criticized it as a "conniving multimedia monster" reflecting "our debauched culture" with "reconstituted evil." Furthermore, the choice to have the season one winner perform the national anthem at the Lincoln Memorial on the first anniversary of the September 11 attacks in 2002 was not well-received. Lisa de Moraes from The Washington Post sarcastically remarked "The terrorists have won" and criticized the commercialism and voting process of the show, noting that the decision to "turn this important site into just another cog in the 'Great American Idol Marketing Mandala'" was left to "millions of girls" and dedicated phone voters, who, despite Fox's claims, were believed to skew the results.

The 1980s saw an intense media focus on the royal family's opinions and private lives, resulting in numerous sensational stories, some of which were not entirely accurate. Kelvin MacKenzie, editor of The Sun, famously instructed his team to create attention-grabbing stories about the royals, regardless of their truth, provided they didn't cause too much trouble. On 21 September 1986, Donald Trelford of The Observer noted that public interest in the royals had blurred the line between fact and fiction, with some newspapers disregarding fact-checking and the truth. The Sunday Times reported on 20 July 1986 that the Queen was concerned about Margaret Thatcher's economic policies, which she believed caused social division, high unemployment, riots, violent miners' strikes, and Thatcher's reluctance to sanction South Africa's apartheid regime. Sources for these claims included royal aide Michael Shea and Commonwealth Secretary-General Shridath Ramphal, though Shea stated his comments were misrepresented and exaggerated. Rumor had it that Thatcher suggested the Queen would support the Social Democratic Party, her political rivals. John Campbell, Thatcher's biographer, dismissed the report as journalistic mischief. Despite alleged tensions, Thatcher later expressed her admiration for the Queen, who honored Thatcher with the Order of Merit and the Order of the Garter after her resignation in favor of John Major. Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney credited Elizabeth with playing a key role behind the scenes in ending apartheid.

The palace spans 108 meters (354 ft) by 120 meters (390 ft), stands 24 meters (79 ft) tall, and encompasses over 77,000 m² (830,000 sq ft) of floor space. Its floor area is smaller than that of the Royal Palace of Madrid, the Papal Palace in Rome, the Louvre in Paris, the Hofburg Palace in Vienna, and the Forbidden City. The palace includes 775 rooms: 19 state rooms, 52 primary bedrooms, 188 staff bedrooms, 92 offices, and 78 bathrooms. The main rooms are located on the piano nobile behind the west-facing garden façade at the palace's rear. The centerpiece of these opulent state rooms is the Music Room, with its large bow as the facade's dominant feature. The Blue and White Drawing Rooms flank the Music Room. At the suite's center, the Picture Gallery serves as a corridor linking the state rooms; it is top-lit and measures 55 yards (50 m) in length. The Gallery features numerous artworks, including pieces by Rembrandt, van Dyck, Rubens, and Vermeer. The Throne Room and the Green Drawing Room extend from the Picture Gallery, with the Green Drawing Room acting as a grand anteroom to the Throne Room, part of the ceremonial route from the Guard Room at the top of the Grand Staircase. The Guard Room houses white marble statues of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert in Roman attire, within a tribune adorned with tapestries. These formal rooms are designated for ceremonial and official events but are accessible to the public each summer.

To strengthen and solidify the dynasty's hold over Central Asia, the Kangxi Emperor personally led military campaigns against the Dzungars in Outer Mongolia. His efforts successfully drove out Galdan's invading forces, allowing these territories to be absorbed into the empire. Galdan ultimately perished during the Dzungar–Qing War. In 1683, Qing forces accepted the surrender of Taiwan from Zheng Keshuang, Koxinga's grandson, who had previously seized Taiwan from the Dutch to use it as a base against the Qing. Zheng Keshuang was granted the title "Duke Haicheng" (海澄公) and was integrated into the Han Chinese Plain Red Banner of the Eight Banners upon relocating to Beijing. Several Ming princes, including the Prince of Ningjing Zhu Shugui and Prince Zhu Honghuan (朱弘桓), had accompanied Koxinga to Taiwan in 1661-1662 and resided in the Kingdom of Tungning. In 1683, the Qing relocated the 17 remaining Ming princes from Taiwan back to mainland China, where they lived in exile, spared from execution. Securing Taiwan allowed Kangxi's troops to engage in a series of conflicts over Albazin, the easternmost outpost of the Tsardom of Russia. Former soldiers from Taiwan, like the rattan shield troops, were also integrated into the Eight Banners and deployed by the Qing against Russian Cossacks at Albazin. The 1689 Treaty of Nerchinsk was China's first formal treaty with a European nation, maintaining a peaceful border for nearly two centuries. Following Galdan's demise, his followers, adherents of Tibetan Buddhism, sought to influence the selection of the next Dalai Lama. In response, Kangxi sent two armies to Lhasa, the Tibetan capital, and appointed a Dalai Lama aligned with Qing interests.

Starting in the 1970s, Stuart Hall's groundbreaking work, alongside contributions from Paul Willis, Dick Hebdige, Tony Jefferson, and Angela McRobbie, sparked an international intellectual movement. This evolving field began to integrate political economy, communication, sociology, social theory, literary and media theory, film/video studies, cultural anthropology, philosophy, museum studies, and art history to analyze cultural phenomena or texts. Researchers in this area often focus on how specific phenomena are connected to issues of ideology, nationality, ethnicity, social class, or gender. Cultural studies are interested in the meanings and practices of everyday life, examining how people engage in activities like watching TV or dining out within a cultural framework. The field explores the meanings and uses people assign to objects and practices, particularly those meanings and practices that exist independently of reason. For example, viewing television to gain a public perspective on historical events is not considered cultural unless referring to the cultural selection of the medium itself; conversely, schoolchildren watching TV after school with friends to "fit in" does qualify, as it lacks a rational basis for participation. Recently, with the global spread of capitalism—a process known as globalization—cultural studies have begun examining local and global resistances to Western dominance. In this context, globalization refers to the spread of Western civilization, which can undermine the cultural integrity of other societies, often being seen as repressive, exploitative, and detrimental to people worldwide.

Libya's economy experienced a shift towards privatization, moving away from the socialist policies of nationalized industries promoted in The Green Book. Government officials insisted they were creating "people's socialism" rather than capitalism. Gaddafi supported these changes, advocating for widespread privatization in a speech in March 2003. By 2003, much of the oil industry was privatized, leading to a $40 billion surge in direct foreign investment by 2004, a sixfold increase from the previous year. Some Libyans opposed these reforms, resulting in public protests. In March 2006, revolutionary hard-liners gained control of the GPC cabinet and slowed the pace of reforms but did not stop them. In 2010, plans were introduced to privatize half of the Libyan economy over the next decade. Despite these economic changes, political liberalization did not occur, with Gaddafi maintaining significant control. However, in March 2010, the government granted more powers to municipal councils. Increasing numbers of reform-minded technocrats took on roles in governance, notably Gaddafi's son, Saif al-Islam Gaddafi, who criticized Libya's human rights situation. He led efforts to draft a new constitution, though it was never implemented, and in October 2009, he was named head of the PSLC. Saif also pushed for tourism and established privately owned media channels in 2008, which were nationalized in 2009 after government criticism. In October 2010, Gaddafi apologized to African leaders for the Arab nations' role in the African slave trade.

Mammalian hair, or pelage, exhibits color variation across different populations, within a single population, and even in individual organisms. In mammalian species, variations in light and dark colors are common, sometimes influenced by age, but often due to other factors. Selective pressures, such as ecological interactions and environmental conditions, frequently drive these color variations to enhance survival. Camouflage is believed to be a key selection pressure influencing mammalian coloration, although sexual selection, communication, and physiological functions also play roles in its evolution. Camouflage helps conceal organisms from predators or prey, making it a primary mechanism for color variation. Coat color can also facilitate intraspecies communication, such as alerting others to predators, indicating reproductive health, aiding mother-offspring communication, and deterring predators. Research suggests that differences in coat color between females and males may provide insights into nutritional and hormonal status, critical for mate selection. Another function of coat color variation is physiological adaptation, like temperature regulation in tropical or arctic climates. Despite significant observations on color variation, much remains unknown about the genetic links between coat color and genes. Known genetic sites affecting pigmentation influence phenotype by 1) changing the spatial distribution of hair pigmentation and 2) modifying hair density and distribution. Quantitative trait mapping is being employed to better understand loci responsible for pigmentation variation, yet the expression of these genes is not fully understood.

In the mid-18th century, during the French Enlightenment, the term "humanism" began to be used in a more ideological sense. In 1765, an anonymous author in a French Enlightenment publication discussed "The general love of humanity ... a virtue hitherto quite nameless among us, and which we will venture to call 'humanism', for the time has come to create a word for such a beautiful and necessary thing." The late 18th and early 19th centuries witnessed the rise of numerous grassroots "philanthropic" and benevolent organizations focused on human betterment and spreading knowledge, some with Christian ties and others without. Following the French Revolution, the notion that human virtue could be cultivated solely through human reason, independent of traditional religious institutions—a view attributed by critics to Enlightenment thinkers like Rousseau—faced fierce opposition from religious and political conservatives like Edmund Burke and Joseph de Maistre, who saw it as humanity's deification. Consequently, "humanism" began to acquire negative connotations. The Oxford English Dictionary notes the word's use by an English clergyman in 1812 to describe those who believed in Christ's "mere humanity" rather than his divine nature, such as Unitarians and Deists. In this polarized climate, where established religious bodies often resisted political and social reforms like voting rights extensions and universal education, liberal reformers and radicals adopted Humanism as an alternative religion centered on humanity. Anarchist Proudhon, known for stating "property is theft," employed "humanism" to depict a "culte, déification de l’humanité" or "worship, deification of humanity." In "L’avenir de la science: pensées de 1848" ("The Future of Knowledge: Thoughts on 1848") (1848–49), Ernest Renan expressed his belief that pure humanism would become the future's religion, celebrating all human aspects and elevating them to moral significance.

In situations involving three or more political parties, it's rare for a single party to secure power independently, leading to the formation of coalition governments. This trend has been notable in the Republic of Ireland since the 1980s and is almost routine in Germany at both national and state levels, as well as in most local constituencies. Since its inception, Iceland has only seen coalition-led governments, typically involving the Independence Party and another, often the Social Democratic Alliance. Similarly, in the Republic of Ireland, no single party has governed alone since 1989, with coalitions consistently led by either Fianna Fáil or Fine Gael. Coalition governments can facilitate political change more readily than systems dominated by one or two parties, but disagreements within a two-party system can hinder policy progress, as seen in the current U.S. political landscape with Democrats and Republicans divided. Despite this, coalition governments can also face significant challenges in enacting policy changes, as demonstrated by post-World War II France and Italy. Conversely, when one party in a two-party system controls all branches, policy shifts can be rapid and impactful, benefiting leaders like Democrats Woodrow Wilson, Franklin Roosevelt, and Lyndon Johnson, as well as Republicans such as Abraham Lincoln and Ronald Reagan. Barack Obama experienced a similar advantage briefly from 2009 to 2011.

Emotions drive social interactions and relationships, linking them closely to basic physiology, especially stress systems. This connection is crucial as emotions engage with the anti-stress complex, including the oxytocin-attachment system, vital for forming bonds. Emotional temperament influences social connectivity and adaptability within intricate social frameworks (Kurt Kortschal 2013). These traits are found in other species and are influenced by genes and their ongoing transmission. DNA sequences provide the instructions for building proteins that constitute our cells. Zygotes need genetic data from parental germ cells, and during speciation, heritable traits that helped ancestors thrive and reproduce are passed on along with new traits that might benefit future generations. Over the five million years since humans and chimpanzees diverged, only about 1.2% of their genetic material has changed. This implies that the differences between us and chimpanzees are encoded in this small DNA portion, including behavioral differences. Researchers studying animal behavior have only found gene-dependent behavioral phenotypes within the same species. In voles (Microtus spp.), slight genetic variations in a vasopressin receptor gene align with significant species differences in social structures and mating systems (Hammock & Young 2005). The FOCP2 gene, another example, plays a role in neural networks related to speech and language (Vargha-Khadem et al. 2005). Its current form in humans differs from chimpanzees by a few mutations and has existed for about 200,000 years, aligning with the emergence of modern humans (Enard et al. 2002). Speech, language, and social organization are foundational to emotions.

The implications are varied as different research fields are increasingly using the concept of identity to explore various phenomena. One significant implication of identity and its construction is evident in occupational settings, particularly in stigmatized or "dirty work" jobs (Hughes, 1951). Tracy and Trethewey (2005) assert that people are drawn to or avoid certain jobs based partly on how much they affirm a "preferred organizational self" (Tracy & Trethewey, 2005, p. 169). Different jobs come with distinct stigmas or prestige. For example, Tracy discusses how correctional officers strive to overcome the stigma of being seen as "glorified maids" (Tracy & Trethewey, 2005). This reflects the process by which individuals justify and value their occupational choices, influencing workplace satisfaction and overall quality of life (Tracy & Scott, 2006, p. 33). Those in such roles must develop ways to create a livable identity. "Crafting a positive sense of self at work is more challenging when one's work is considered 'dirty' by societal standards" (Tracy & Scott, 2006, p. 7). Managing this taint isn't just about feeling good in the job. Employees who must navigate discourses questioning their work's legitimacy or face challenges transforming dirty work into a source of pride may find that blaming the client helps affirm their identity (Tracy & Scott, 2006, p. 33).

In their 2003 paper "Human Genetic Diversity and the Nonexistence of Biological Races," Jeffrey Long and Rick Kittles offer a detailed critique of using FST to assess human populations. They argue that the commonly cited 85% figure is misleading, as it suggests each human population contains, on average, 85% of all genetic diversity. This view, they suggest, incorrectly portrays human population history by treating all groups as independent. A more accurate understanding recognizes that some human groups are ancestral to others, forming paraphyletic groups. For instance, under the recent African origin theory, the African population is paraphyletic to all other human groups, as it represents the source from which non-African populations originate. However, these non-African groups stem from a small, non-representative sample of the African population. As a result, non-African groups are more closely related to each other and to particular African groups (likely East Africans) than to others, and the migration out of Africa involved a genetic bottleneck, leaving behind much of Africa’s diversity. This perspective indicates that human population movements result in interconnected groups rather than independent ones, with genetic diversity diminishing progressively with distance from Africa. Long and Kittles conclude that instead of 85% of genetic diversity being present in all populations, nearly 100% exists within a single African population, while only about 70% is found in populations from places like New Guinea. Despite this, they maintain that the global human population remains genetically homogeneous compared to other mammalian populations.

During Darwin's lifetime, his book was translated widely, but challenges emerged with translating concepts and metaphors, and some translations were influenced by the translators' personal agendas. Darwin distributed copies in France and Germany, hoping suitable translators would come forward, as they had to arrange their own deals with local publishers. He welcomed Heinrich Georg Bronn, a distinguished elderly naturalist and geologist, to translate it into German. However, Bronn's translation in 1860 included his own ideas, introducing controversial themes that Darwin had intentionally left out. Bronn translated "favoured races" as "perfected races" and added essays on topics like the origin of life, along with a final chapter on religious implications inspired by his belief in Naturphilosophie. In 1862, Bronn released a second edition based on the third English version and Darwin's suggestions but died shortly afterward. Darwin then worked closely with Julius Victor Carus, who produced an improved translation in 1867. In France, Darwin struggled to find a translator, and the 1862 translation by Clémence Royer included an introduction praising Darwin's ideas as an alternative to religious revelation, while promoting concepts foreshadowing social Darwinism and eugenics, along with many notes offering her own answers to Darwin's doubts. Despite corresponding with Royer for the 1866 and 1870 editions, Darwin had difficulty getting her to remove her notes and was dissatisfied with these versions. Satisfaction came only in 1876 with Edmond Barbier's translation. A Dutch version by Tiberius Cornelis Winkler appeared in 1860. By 1864, Italian and Russian versions were available. Within Darwin's lifetime, translations also appeared in Swedish (1871), Danish (1872), Polish (1873), Hungarian (1873–1874), Spanish (1877), and Serbian (1878). By 1977, the book had been translated into 18 additional languages.

Hegel aims to retain the truths he sees in German idealism, particularly Kant's belief that ethical reasoning transcends finite desires. For Hegel, there must be an alignment between thought and being for a "subject" (any human observer) to understand any "object" (any external entity, possibly including another human). According to Hegel's idea of "subject-object identity," both the subject and the object share Spirit (Hegel's non-supernatural, redefined concept of "God") as their conceptual inner reality, making them identical in this sense. However, until Spirit achieves "self-realization" and evolves into Absolute Spirit, the subject (a human mind) mistakenly perceives every "object" it encounters as "alien," or separate from the subject. In Hegel's terms, "The object is revealed to it [to the subject] as something alien, and it does not recognize itself." Self-realization occurs when Hegel (as part of Spirit's non-supernatural Mind, the collective mind of humanity) understands that every "object" is actually part of himself because both subject and object are fundamentally Spirit. When self-realization is achieved and Spirit becomes Absolute Spirit, the "finite" (human) transforms into the "infinite" ("God," divine), supplanting the imaginary or "picture-thinking" supernatural God of theism: humanity becomes God. Tucker describes it as "Hegelianism . . . is a religion of self-worship whose fundamental theme is given in Hegel's image of the man who aspires to be God himself, who demands 'something more, namely infinity.'" Hegel's portrayal is "of a self-glorifying humanity striving compulsively, and ultimately succeeding, to ascend to divinity."

The Israelites experienced political independence twice in ancient times: initially during the era of the Biblical judges, and subsequently during the United Monarchy. After the United Monarchy dissolved, the territory split into the kingdoms of Israel and Judah. The term "Jew" is derived from the Roman word "Judean," which referred to someone from Judah, the southern kingdom. Although the Torah does not mention this change in identity from "Israelites" to "Jews," it is clearly illustrated in the Book of Esther, part of the Ketuvim section of the Jewish Tanakh, written in the 4th century BCE. In 587 BC, Nebuchadnezzar II, ruler of the Neo-Babylonian Empire, besieged Jerusalem, demolished the First Temple, and deported prominent Judah citizens. By 586 BC, Judah had lost its independence, leaving its remaining Jewish inhabitants stateless. The Babylonian exile concluded in 539 BCE when the Achaemenid Empire overtook Babylon, and Cyrus the Great permitted the exiled Jews to return to Yehud and reconstruct their Temple, completed in 515 BCE. Yehud remained a tranquil province of the Achaemenid Empire until about 333 BCE, when Alexander the Great conquered the Empire. Jews again enjoyed political autonomy during the Hasmonean dynasty from 140 to 37 BCE and partially under the Herodian dynasty from 37 BCE to 6 CE. Following the Second Temple's destruction in 70 CE, most Jews have resided in the diaspora. As a minority group in most countries (except Israel), Jews have often faced persecution, leading to fluctuating populations and dispersal throughout history.

At the Tokyo Game Show in September 2012, Sony unveiled a new, slimmer redesign of the PS3, known as the CECH-4000, set for release later that year. This redesign, called the Super Slim model, came in three versions: a 500 GB hard drive, a 250 GB hard drive not available in PAL regions, and a 12 GB flash storage version exclusive to PAL regions. The 12 GB model's storage can be upgraded with a standalone 250 GB hard drive. Additionally, a vertical stand was introduced for the model. In the UK, the 500 GB version launched on September 28, 2012, followed by the 12 GB version on October 12, 2012. In the US, the Super Slim initially launched as bundled consoles: the 250 GB model, bundled with the Game of the Year edition of Uncharted 3: Drake's Deception, was released on September 25, 2012, and the 500 GB model, bundled with Assassin's Creed III, on October 30, 2012. In Japan, the black Super Slim model debuted on October 4, 2012, and the white model on November 22, 2012. This version is 20% smaller and 25% lighter than the previous Slim model and features a manual sliding disc cover instead of the motorized slot-loading one. The white Super Slim model reached the US on January 27, 2013, as part of the Instant Game Collection Bundle. In Japan, the Garnet Red and Azurite Blue models launched on February 28, 2013. The Garnet Red version became available in North America on March 12, 2013, as part of the God of War: Ascension bundle with 500 GB storage, including God of War: Ascension and the God of War Saga. The Azurite Blue model was released exclusively at GameStop with a 250 GB hard drive.

In 1919, after the Treaty of Versailles, France regained control of the city without a referendum, aligning with U.S. President Woodrow Wilson's "Fourteen Points." The official date was set on Armistice Day. It's uncertain if a referendum in Strasbourg would have favored France, as political parties advocating for an autonomous Alsace or ties with France had minimal support in the last Reichstag and local elections. However, pro-French Alsatian autonomists gained significant rural support and in other towns since Germany annexed the region in 1871. This movement began with the first Reichstag elections, where those elected were known as "les députés protestataires," demanding a return to France until Bismarck's departure in 1890. In the final Reichstag election in Strasbourg and nearby areas, the Social Democrats prevailed. The city, the region's administrative hub, had many Germans appointed by Berlin, and its economic prosperity attracted more Germans. This might explain the voting disparity between rural areas and Strasbourg. After the war, many Germans left Strasbourg, either voluntarily or after being denounced by locals or expelled by the new authorities. The Saverne Affair remained a significant memory among Alsatians.

Zhejiang's primary manufacturing sectors include electromechanical industries, textiles, chemicals, food, and construction materials. Recently, the region has pioneered its unique "Zhejiang model," focusing on fostering entrepreneurship, emphasizing agile small businesses, significant public infrastructure investments, and mass production of low-cost goods for both domestic and international markets. This strategy has elevated Zhejiang to one of China's wealthiest provinces, with the "Zhejiang spirit" becoming legendary nationwide. However, some economists express concerns about the model's sustainability, citing inefficiencies and excessive dependency on raw materials and public utilities, and pointing out that the numerous small enterprises producing bulk cheap goods struggle to transition to more advanced industries. Zhejiang's economic focal point is shifting from North Zhejiang, centered in Hangzhou, towards the southeast, around Wenzhou and Taizhou. By 2009, urban residents in Zhejiang had a per capita disposable income of 24,611 yuan (US$3,603), with an annual real growth of 8.3%, while rural residents' per capita pure income was 10,007 yuan (US$1,465), growing at 8.1% year-on-year. In 2011, Zhejiang's nominal GDP reached 3.20 trillion yuan (US$506 billion) with a per capita GDP of 44,335 yuan (US$6,490). In 2009, its primary, secondary, and tertiary industries were valued at 116.2 billion yuan (US$17 billion), 1.1843 trillion yuan (US$173.4 billion), and 982.7 billion yuan (US$143.9 billion), respectively.

In its early years, MCA produced discs for several other companies, such as Paramount, Disney, and Warner Bros. These companies often placed their own names on the disc jackets to indicate that MCA did not own the movies. After Discovision Associates closed in early 1982, Universal Studio's videodisc label, MCA Videodisc, which retained that name until 1984, started reissuing many DiscoVision titles. Unfortunately, several reissues, like Battlestar Galactica and Jaws, were time-compressed versions of their original CAV or CLV DiscoVision releases. The time-compressed CLV version of Jaws lost its original soundtrack, as incidental background music was replaced due to licensing costs; the original music wasn't available until the THX LaserDisc box set came out in 1995. One MCA DiscoVision release, The Electric Horseman, a Universal/Columbia co-production, remains unavailable in any home video format with its original score; even the latest DVD has substantial music replacements, including changes to both instrumental scores and Willie Nelson's songs. MCA's release of Universal's Howard the Duck shows only the start credits in widescreen, switching to 4:3 for the remainder of the film. This was the sole disc-based version for many years until widescreen DVDs with extras were released. Additionally, the LaserDisc release of E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial uniquely includes a cut scene of Harrison Ford as the school headmaster scolding Elliott for freeing the frogs in biology class.

In southeast Europe, agrarian societies emerged in the 7th millennium BC, as evidenced by one of Europe's earliest farming sites found in Vashtëmi, southeastern Albania, dating back to 6,500 BC. Anthropomorphic figurines appeared in the Balkans around 6000 BC and in Central Europe by about 5800 BC (La Hoguette). Early cultural complexes in the region include the Sesklo culture in Thessaly, which expanded into the Balkans, leading to cultures like Starčevo-Körös (Cris), Linearbandkeramik, and Vinča. Neolithic traditions spread west and north through cultural diffusion and migration, reaching northwestern Europe by approximately 4500 BC. The Vinča culture possibly developed the earliest writing system, the Vinča signs, though archaeologist Shan Winn suggests they were more likely pictograms and ideograms than a fully developed writing system. The Cucuteni-Trypillian culture created large settlements in Romania, Moldova, and Ukraine between 5300 and 2300 BC. Ġgantija's megalithic temple complexes on Gozo and Mnajdra (Malta) are notable for their massive Neolithic structures, the oldest dating to around 3600 BC. The Hypogeum of Ħal-Saflieni in Paola, Malta, is a subterranean structure excavated around 2500 BC, originally a sanctuary, later a necropolis, and is the only prehistoric underground temple globally, showcasing unique stone artistry in Malta. Post-2500 BC, the Maltese Islands were uninhabited for several decades until new Bronze Age immigrants arrived, introducing a culture that cremated its dead and built smaller megalithic structures called dolmens. These dolmens often feature small chambers with large slabs atop upright stones, attributed to a population distinct from the earlier temple builders. This population is believed to have come from Sicily due to similarities between Maltese dolmens and small constructions on the Mediterranean's largest island.

According to Popper, knowledge is objective in that it is either objectively true or resembles truth, and it possesses an ontological status, existing independently of the individual who knows it (Objective Knowledge: An Evolutionary Approach, 1972). He introduced the concept of three worlds: World One, which consists of the physical realm or physical states; World Two, which includes the realm of the mind, encompassing mental states, ideas, and perceptions; and World Three, which comprises the entirety of human knowledge as represented in various forms, being the manifestations of the mental world in physical form (such as books, papers, paintings, and symphonies). Popper argued that World Three is created by individuals much like a path is made by animals, possessing an existence and evolutionary path independent of any single individual. He believed that World Three's impact on an individual's mind (World Two) is at least as significant as that of the physical world (World One). In essence, an individual's knowledge is as much a product of the collective body of human knowledge as it is of direct personal experience. Thus, the expansion of human knowledge can be seen as resulting from the independent development of World Three. However, many modern philosophers, like Daniel Dennett, have not accepted Popper's Three Worlds theory, primarily due to its perceived similarity to mind-body dualism.

In the United Kingdom, the strict separation of powers was not practiced, and its political structure often served as a model for the U.S. Constitution. In the UK's Westminster system, which emphasizes parliamentary sovereignty and responsible government, Parliament (comprising the Sovereign, House of Lords, and House of Commons) held ultimate lawmaking authority. Both the executive and judiciary acted on behalf of the King, with the King's Ministers typically being members of Parliament. The government relied on maintaining a majority in the House of Commons. Notably, the Lord Chancellor held roles in both the judiciary and legislative branches as the sole judge in the Court of Chancery and the presiding officer in the House of Lords. Thus, despite frequent disagreements among branches, the UK government structure often breached strict separation of powers. Similarly, in 18th-century America, some states did not adhere strictly to this principle. For instance, in New Jersey, the Governor was a member of the state's highest court and presided over one legislative house. In Delaware, the President was part of the Court of Appeals, and the legislative leaders also operated as Vice Presidents in the executive department. Additionally, in Delaware and Pennsylvania, executive council members simultaneously served as judges. However, several southern states, such as Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and Georgia, explicitly mandated the separation and distinction of governmental branches.

Ottoman madaris provided various fields of study, including calligraphic, oral, and intellectual sciences, but their main purpose was to serve as Islamic centers for spiritual education. The ultimate aim of all knowledge, particularly the spiritual sciences, was to understand God. Religion largely determined the relevance and importance of each discipline. İnalcık states that sciences beneficial to religion were valued, while those like astrology were not. Even though subjects like mathematics and logic were included in the madrasa curriculum, they were fundamentally religious in nature. Mathematics, for instance, was taught with a religious motivation. The Ottoman medreses' Ulema believed opposing logic and mathematics was pointless, as these fields encouraged correct thinking, aiding in discovering divine truths—emphasizing the "divine." Philosophy was permitted only to support Islamic doctrines. Thus, madaris were primarily religious institutions for Islamic teachings in the Ottoman realm. Scholars like Goffman suggest Ottoman society was tolerant and pluralistic, yet schools, the main learning centers, were significantly religious and Islam-focused. Similarly, in Europe, Jewish children learned Hebrew and prayer texts at home before attending synagogue-run schools to study the Torah. Wiesner-Hanks notes that Protestants also prioritized teaching "proper religious values." This reflects that in the early modern period, both Ottomans and Europeans shared similar views on school management and focus. Therefore, Ottoman madaris, while offering a diverse curriculum, ultimately aimed to strengthen Islamic practices and beliefs, paralleling modern schools in their breadth of subjects.

Thuringia's landscapes are remarkably varied. In the far north lie the Harz mountains, leading to the fertile Goldene Aue floodplain around Nordhausen, with the Helme as its key river. The north-west features the Eichsfeld, a hilly and occasionally forested area from which the Leine river originates. The central and northern regions of Thuringia are characterized by the 3000 km² Thuringian Basin, a very fertile, flat land around the Unstrut river, encircled by the following hill chains (clockwise from the north-west): Dün, Hainleite, Windleite, Kyffhäuser, Hohe Schrecke, Schmücke, Finne, Ettersberg, Steigerwald, Thuringian Forest, Hörselberge, and Hainich. Within the Basin are the smaller hill ranges of Fahner Höhe and Heilinger Höhen. South of the Basin is the Land's largest mountain range, comprising the Thuringian Forest in the north-west, the Thuringian Highland centrally, and the Franconian Forest in the south-east, mostly forested, with Großer Beerberg (983 m) as Thuringia's highest peak. The Werra river valley to the south-west separates the Forest from the Rhön Mountains to the west and the Grabfeld plain to the south. Eastern Thuringia, defined as the area east of the Saale and Loquitz valleys, features a hilly landscape, gradually rising from the flat north to the mountainous south. The Saale to the west and the Weiße Elster to the east are major rivers flowing from south to north, forming densely populated valleys. Between them, the flat, forested Holzland to the north, the fertile Orlasenke in the center, and the hilly, largely unforested Vogtland to the south are found. The far eastern region, east of Weiße Elster, is known as Osterland or Altenburger Land along the Pleiße river, a flat, fertile, and densely populated agricultural area.
