Feynman did not oppose the quark model; for example, when the fifth quark was discovered in 1977, he quickly noted to his students that this discovery indicated a sixth quark’s existence, which was confirmed in the decade following his death.

In late 1203, King John made an attempt to relieve Château Gaillard, which was under siege by Philip and crucially guarded Normandy's eastern flank. He devised a coordinated plan involving both land and naval forces. Historians today see this as inventive but too complex for the era's capabilities. Philip's forces thwarted John's efforts, prompting him to shift his focus to Brittany, hoping to divert Philip from eastern Normandy. While John managed to cause considerable destruction in Brittany, Philip's main advance into eastern Normandy remained undeterred. Historians have mixed views on John's military acumen during this campaign, with most recent analyses deeming his efforts adequate but not noteworthy. John's position soon worsened, as Philip and his predecessors had cultivated the eastern Normandy border for years, and Angevin control in the south weakened due to Richard's earlier decisions regarding key castles. John's reliance on routier mercenaries in central areas further eroded his support, paving the way for Angevin power to collapse. John retreated across the Channel in December, instructing the establishment of a new defensive line west of Château Gaillard. In March 1204, Château Gaillard fell. The death of John's mother Eleanor the following month was not only a personal loss but also jeopardized Angevin alliances across southern France. Philip bypassed the new defenses and struck deep into the Duchy, meeting little opposition. By August, Philip had seized Normandy and pushed south to capture Anjou and Poitou, leaving John with only the Duchy of Aquitaine on the Continent.

In 2013, a study led by Martin B. Richards at the University of Huddersfield in England investigated Ashkenazi mitochondrial DNA and reached conclusions supporting the pre-2006 origin hypothesis. This study analyzed the entire 16,600 DNA units of mitochondrial DNA from all their subjects, unlike the 2006 Behar study, which examined only 1,000 units. The research revealed that the four primary Ashkenazi female founders had lineage rooted in Europe dating back 10,000 to 20,000 years, with most other minor founders also showing deep European ancestry. The study concluded that the majority of Ashkenazi maternal lineages did not originate from the Near East or the Caucasus but were integrated within Europe, primarily from Italian and Old French origins. Richards highlighted, "[N]one [of the mtDNA] came from the North Caucasus, located along the border between Europe and Asia between the Black and Caspian seas. All of our presently available studies including my own, should thoroughly debunk one of the most questionable, but still tenacious, hypotheses: that most Ashkenazi Jews can trace their roots to the mysterious Khazar Kingdom that flourished during the ninth century in the region between the Byzantine Empire and the Persian Empire." The study estimated that 80 percent of Ashkenazi maternal lineage is from European women, 8 percent from the Near East, with the rest being of undetermined origin. These findings suggest a significant role for the conversion of women in the development of Ashkenazi communities.

At the 1912 Salon d'Automne, an architectural installation called Maison Cubiste (Cubist House) was showcased, created by Raymond Duchamp-Villon and André Mare with several collaborators. During the assembly of this Maison Cubiste, Metzinger and Gleizes authored Du "Cubisme", where they emphasized that art should be autonomous and not driven by decorative elements. They considered decorative work as the "antithesis of the picture," arguing that "the true picture" is self-contained and adaptable to various settings, from churches to studies, without needing immediate comprehension. Instead, it should gradually guide the viewer's mind into its depths. Such art harmonizes universally, described as an "organism." Christopher Green noted that Mare's designs were accepted because they preserved the independence of Cubist art, involving artists like Gleizes, Metzinger, Marie Laurencin, the Duchamp brothers (with Raymond designing the facade), and Mare's friends Léger and Roger La Fresnaye. La Maison Cubiste was a fully furnished model with a staircase, iron banisters, a living room—Salon Bourgeois featuring works by Marcel Duchamp, Metzinger (Woman with a Fan), Gleizes, Laurencin, and Léger—and a bedroom. It exemplified L'art décoratif, offering a space for Cubist art within modern, bourgeois comfort. Visitors at the Salon d'Automne walked through a life-sized 10-by-3-meter plaster model of the facade's ground floor, designed by Duchamp-Villon. This installation was later displayed at the 1913 Armory Show in New York, Chicago, and Boston, listed as Raymond Duchamp-Villon, number 609, under "Facade architectural, plaster" (Façade architecturale).

Today, many rock musicians incorporate mandolins into their music, often preferring single-stringed electric versions over double-stringed acoustic ones. Tim Brennan of the Irish-American punk band Dropkick Murphys is one such example. Alongside electric guitars, bass, and drums, the band integrates instruments from traditional Celtic music, such as the mandolin, tin whistle, and Great Highland bagpipes, to enhance their distinct sound. The 1991 R.E.M. hit "Losing My Religion" prominently features simple mandolin riffs by guitarist Peter Buck, who also played mandolin in nearly a dozen other tracks. This single reached No. 4 on the Billboard Hot 100 and topped the rock and alternative charts. Luther Dickinson of North Mississippi Allstars and The Black Crowes frequently uses the mandolin, notably in the Black Crowes song "Locust Street." System of A Down, an Armenian American rock group, extensively used the mandolin on their 2005 albums Mezmerize and Hypnotize. The pop punk band Green Day also incorporated mandolin in their 2000 album, Warning. Boyd Tinsley from the Dave Matthews Band has played an electric mandolin since 2005. The Decemberists' Colin Meloy and Chris Funk regularly feature the mandolin in their music. Nancy Wilson, rhythm guitarist for Heart, utilizes a mandolin in "Dream of the Archer" from the album Little Queen and their cover of Led Zeppelin's "The Battle of Evermore." The song "Show Me Heaven" by Maria McKee, the theme for the film Days of Thunder, prominently includes a mandolin.

In 1951, President Truman, reflecting widespread support for Dwight D. Eisenhower to run for president, urged him to seek the office as a Democrat. However, Eisenhower expressed his disagreements with the Democratic Party and identified himself and his family as Republicans. The Republican Party launched a "Draft Eisenhower" initiative to encourage him to enter the 1952 presidential race, aiming to oppose non-interventionist Senator Robert A. Taft. Convincing Eisenhower to run was challenging; he needed assurance that the political climate required his candidacy and that there was public demand for him as President. Henry Cabot Lodge, his campaign manager, and others eventually persuaded him, leading to his resignation from NATO in June 1952 to campaign full-time. Eisenhower secured the nomination by defeating Taft, notably gaining crucial delegate support from Texas. His campaign gained traction with the catchy slogan "I Like Ike." To succeed, Eisenhower distanced himself from Roosevelt's Yalta policy and Truman's strategies in Korea and China—areas he had previously been involved with. To win over the conservative Old Guard of the Republican Party, he chose Richard M. Nixon as his Vice-Presidential running mate, thereby adding an anti-communist stance and youthful energy to balance Eisenhower's seniority.

In 2006, Morgan Stanley acquired 20 acres (8.1 ha) just north of the Showboat Atlantic City Hotel and Casino for a new casino resort, projected to cost over $2 billion. Revel Entertainment Group was chosen as the developer for this project, named the Revel Casino. The venture faced numerous challenges, the most significant being in April 2010 when Morgan Stanley, which owned 90% of Revel Entertainment Group, decided to stop funding the construction and put its investment in Revel up for sale. Earlier in 2010, the New Jersey state legislature had passed a bill providing tax incentives to lure new investors to complete the project, but a Fairleigh Dickinson University's PublicMind poll in March 2010 found that 60% of voters opposed the legislation, with two-thirds of the opponents expressing strong disapproval. Eventually, Governor Chris Christie offered Revel $261 million in state tax credits to support the casino once it was operational. By March 2011, exterior work on Revel was finished, and interior construction resumed after securing the required funds. The casino had a soft opening in April 2012 and fully opened by May 2012. However, by February 2013, following substantial losses and a valuation drop from $2.4 billion to $450 million, Revel filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy. The casino was restructured but couldn't sustain operations and filed for bankruptcy again on June 19, 2014. It was put on the market, but with no acceptable offers, the resort closed on September 2, 2014.

The final key factor in identity development is self-esteem, which refers to how individuals perceive and feel about their self-concept and identity. Most self-esteem theories suggest a universal drive among people of all genders and ages to preserve, protect, and enhance their self-esteem. Contrary to popular belief, there is no proven significant decline in self-esteem during adolescence. While "barometric self-esteem" can fluctuate and lead to distress and anxiety, baseline self-esteem remains quite stable through adolescent years. The reliability of global self-esteem measures has been questioned, with many advocating for more specific scales that could better capture the adolescent experience. Girls tend to have high self-esteem when they engage in supportive friendships, with the primary benefit being social and moral support. When they lack friends' approval or common interests to share, girls often experience low self-esteem. Conversely, boys focus more on asserting independence and defining their relationship to authority, gaining high self-esteem from successfully influencing peers. However, the inability to win or maintain romantic affection, regardless of sexual orientation, significantly contributes to low self-esteem in adolescent boys. After a romantic relationship ends, both men and women often experience low self-esteem, leading to symptoms like depression and hopelessness. Studies indicate that women are twice as likely to suffer from depression, while men are three to four times more likely to commit suicide (Mearns, 1991; Ustun & Sartorius, 1995).

For its full launch in North America, the Nintendo Entertainment System was gradually introduced over several years with four distinct bundles: the Deluxe Set, the Control Deck, the Action Set, and the Power Set. The Deluxe Set, priced at US$199.99 (about $475 in 2016), featured R.O.B., an NES Zapper light gun, two controllers, and two Game Paks: Gyromite and Duck Hunt. The Basic Set was available for US$89.99 without a game, and for US$99.99, it was bundled with "Super Mario Bros." The Action Set, sold in 1988 for US$149.99, included the Control Deck, two controllers, an NES Zapper, and a dual Game Pak with Super Mario Bros. and Duck Hunt. In 1989, the Power Set offered the console, two controllers, a NES Zapper, a Power Pad, and a triple Game Pak featuring Super Mario Bros, Duck Hunt, and World Class Track Meet. In 1990, the Sports Set was introduced, comprising the console, an NES Satellite infrared wireless multitap adapter, four controllers, and a dual Game Pak with Super Spike V'Ball and Nintendo World Cup. Two additional bundles using the original NES model followed. The Challenge Set of 1992 included the console, two controllers, and a Super Mario Bros. 3 Game Pak, priced at US$89.99. The Basic Set, initially released in 1987, was repackaged for US$89.99. This version included just the console and two controllers, without a game cartridge, but featured the Official Nintendo Player's Guide, detailing every NES game available at that time.

Following a period of internal strife for the Liberals, ex-Treasurer John Howard and former Foreign Minister Andrew Peacock vied for dominance. The Australian economy was grappling with the early 1990s recession, resulting in unemployment peaking at 11.4% in 1992. Under Dr. John Hewson, the opposition unveiled the 650-page Fightback! policy in November 1991, which proposed bold economic liberal measures. These included introducing a Goods and Services Tax (GST), altering Medicare by removing bulk billing for non-concession holders, imposing a nine-month cap on unemployment benefits, reforming industrial relations by abolishing awards, cutting $13 billion in personal income tax for middle and upper earners, reducing government spending by $10 billion, eliminating state payroll taxes, and privatizing many government enterprises. These changes marked a shift from the Keynesian economic conservatism of previous Coalition governments, with the 15 percent GST as the plan's centerpiece. Throughout 1992, Labor Prime Minister Paul Keating campaigned against the Fightback package, particularly the GST, labeling it a burden shift from the wealthy to the working class through indirect taxation. Persistent public and pressure group opposition forced Hewson to exempt food from the GST, raising questions about the complexity of determining which foods would be exempt. Hewson's struggle to clarify this was highlighted in the infamous birthday cake interview, seen by some as a pivotal moment in the election campaign. Keating secured a record fifth consecutive term for Labor in the 1993 election. Eventually, several proposals were partially enacted: some during the Keating government, but more extensively during Howard's term, notably the GST, while unemployment benefits and bulk billing were adjusted under the Abbott government.

In 356, Constantius exiled Liberius, giving him three days to comply. Liberius was sent to Beroea in Thrace. Constantius offered him costly gifts to adopt the Arian view, but Liberius refused, even rejecting 500 gold pieces meant for his expenses, suggesting they be given to flatterers instead. When the empress sent a similar gift, Liberius advised the messenger to believe in Christ and not persecute the Church. Attempts to leave gifts in the Church were thwarted by Liberius. Consequently, Constantius had him brought to Milan under strict guard. During a conference, as recorded by Theodoret, Liberius boldly informed Constantius that Athanasius had been acquitted in Sardica and that his accusers were proven liars and impostors. He argued it was unjust to condemn someone without a legal conviction. Although Constantius had no rebuttal, he impatiently ordered Liberius back into exile. Liberius complied. Two years later, Constantius visited Rome for his twentieth anniversary as emperor. The ladies petitioned for Liberius’s return, which Constantius agreed to on the condition that Liberius comply with the court bishops. Liberius signed the condemnation of Athanasius and accepted an Arian creed from Sirmium. However, once reinstated, he proclaimed his support for the Nicene Creed, as noted by Theodoret. Constantius and his court bishops had their beliefs, while Athanasius remained loyal to the orthodox creed. Constantius, a declared Arian, became sole ruler in 350 after his brother Constans’s death.

The Montana Territory was established on April 26, 1864, following the U.S. passage of the Organic Act. Even before it officially became a territory, schools began to emerge as families settled in the region. Initially, these were subscription schools often held in teachers' homes. The first documented formal school was at Fort Owen in the Bitterroot Valley in 1862, catering to Native American children and the offspring of Fort Owen employees. This school, led by Mr. Robinson, started in early winter and concluded by February 28. In 1863, Thomas Dimsdale opened another early subscription school in Virginia City, charging students $1.75 per week. The first Montana Territorial Legislative Assembly convened in 1864, authorizing counties to levy taxes for schools, laying the groundwork for public education. Madison County was the first to utilize these taxes to establish a public school in Virginia City in 1886. Although the school was set to open in January 1866, harsh weather delayed its start until March, with the school year extending through summer to August 17. Among the first teachers was Sarah Raymond, a 25-year-old who arrived in Virginia City by wagon train in 1865. To certify as a teacher, she passed a home-based test and paid a $6 fee in gold dust. With support from an assistant teacher, Mrs. Farley, Raymond taught 50 to 60 students daily from a total enrollment of 81. Raymond earned $125 per month, while Mrs. Farley received $75. The school lacked textbooks, relying instead on various books brought by emigrants. Although Sarah stopped teaching the next year, she later became the superintendent of schools in Madison County.

On 20 June 1794, Burke was thanked by the Commons for his role in the Hastings Trial, after which he promptly resigned and was succeeded by his son Richard. In August 1794, Burke experienced a devastating loss with Richard's death, to whom he was deeply attached and in whom he saw potential that others did not recognize, although Richard had made contributions to the early fight for Catholic emancipation. King George III, appreciative of Burke's stance on the French Revolution, intended to bestow the title of Earl of Beaconsfield upon him, but the death of his son made such an honor and its benefits undesirable to Burke, leading him to accept only a pension of £2,500. This pension was criticized by the Duke of Bedford and the Earl of Lauderdale, prompting Burke to respond in his "Letter to a Noble Lord" (1796), stating: "It cannot at this time be too often repeated; line upon line; precept upon precept; until it comes into the currency of a proverb, To innovate is not to reform". He defended his pension as earned by merit, contrasting it with the Duke of Bedford’s inherited rewards, noting, "Mine was from a mild and benevolent sovereign; his from Henry the Eighth". Burke also alluded to the potential consequences for those with revolutionary ideas, and included an explanation of the British constitution.

The nation swiftly descended into a civil war, marked by various factions battling each other, often based on clan loyalties. During this period, over 500,000 residents fled due to persecution, increasing poverty, and the lure of better economic prospects in the West or other former Soviet republics. Emomali Rahmon assumed power in 1992, defeating former prime minister Abdumalik Abdullajanov in a November presidential election with 58% of the vote. The elections occurred soon after the war ended, leaving Tajikistan in complete devastation, with over 100,000 estimated dead and about 1.2 million people displaced as refugees both inside and outside the country. In 1997, a ceasefire was achieved between Rahmon and opposition groups under Gerd D. Merrem, Special Representative to the Secretary General, an outcome widely acclaimed as a successful United Nations peacekeeping effort. The ceasefire promised 30% of ministerial roles to the opposition. In the 1999 elections, criticized by opposition groups and foreign observers as unfair, Rahmon was re-elected with 98% of the vote. In 2006, he won again with 79% of the vote, beginning his third term. Several opposition parties boycotted the 2006 election, and the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe (OSCE) criticized it, although observers from the Commonwealth of Independent States deemed the elections legal and transparent. Rahmon's administration faced further criticism from the OSCE in October 2010 for media censorship and repression. The OSCE alleged that the Tajik Government censored both local and foreign websites and conducted tax inspections on independent printing houses, leading to the shutdown of several independent newspapers.

Numerous theories have been proposed regarding Yale's prominence in national elections since the Vietnam War era. Various sources highlight the legacy of campus activism at Yale dating back to the 1960s, as well as the intellectual impact of Reverend William Sloane Coffin on many future candidates. Yale President Richard Levin attributes this trend to the university's emphasis on being "a laboratory for future leaders," an institutional focus initiated by past Yale Presidents Alfred Whitney Griswold and Kingman Brewster. Richard H. Brodhead, former dean of Yale College and now Duke University's president, remarked on the importance placed on community engagement in admissions and the strong tradition of volunteerism at Yale. Historian Gaddis Smith mentions "an ethos of organized activity" at Yale in the 20th century, which saw John Kerry lead the Yale Political Union's Liberal Party, George Pataki the Conservative Party, and Joseph Lieberman managing the Yale Daily News. Camille Paglia emphasizes Yale's networking and elitism rooted in "a web of friendships and affiliations built up in school." CNN notes that George W. Bush may have gained from admissions preferences as the "son and grandson of alumni" and as part of a politically influential family. Journalists Elisabeth Bumiller of The New York Times and James Fallows of The Atlantic Monthly attribute Yale's impact to a culture of community and cooperation among students, faculty, and administration, which minimizes self-interest and strengthens dedication to others.

During King George V's reign, the last significant construction occurred in 1913 when Sir Aston Webb remodeled Blore's 1850 East Front to partially mirror Giacomo Leoni's Lyme Park in Cheshire. The new main façade, made of Portland stone, was intended as a backdrop to the Victoria Memorial, a grand statue of Queen Victoria standing outside the main gates. Upon succeeding Edward VII in 1910, George V, known for his more serious demeanor, shifted the focus from extravagant parties to official entertaining and royal responsibilities. He organized command performances featuring jazz musicians like the Original Dixieland Jazz Band in 1919, marking the first jazz performance for a head of state, along with Sidney Bechet and Louis Armstrong in 1932. This earned the palace a nomination in 2009 for a (Kind of) Blue Plaque by the Brecon Jazz Festival, recognizing its significant contribution to jazz in the UK. Queen Mary, George V's wife, was an art enthusiast who took a deep interest in enhancing the Royal Collection of furniture and art. She also oversaw the installation of new fixtures, such as a pair of marble Empire-style chimneypieces by Benjamin Vulliamy from 1810, placed in the Bow Room on the ground floor. Additionally, Queen Mary was instrumental in decorating the Blue Drawing Room, a 69-foot-long room formerly called the South Drawing Room, featuring a specially designed coffered ceiling with large gilt console brackets by Nash.

The exits of Núñez and van Gaal were barely acknowledged by fans compared to the departure of Luís Figo, the club's vice-captain at the time. Figo was adored and seen as a local hero by Catalans. However, his move to arch-rivals Real Madrid left Barcelona fans devastated, and he faced intense hostility during his visits to Camp Nou. On his first return, he was met with a piglet's head and a full whiskey bottle thrown from the stands. The next three years saw the club's fortunes wane, with a series of managerial changes. van Gaal was succeeded by Llorenç Serra Ferrer, who, despite significant player investments in summer 2000, led the team to a lackluster league performance and an embarrassing first-round exit from the Champions League, resulting in his late-season dismissal. Carles Rexach, a long-serving coach, was appointed temporarily and managed to secure a Champions League spot on the season's final day. Although Rexach saw better results in La Liga and reached the Champions League semi-finals, he was not seen as a long-term solution, paving the way for Louis van Gaal's return as manager. His second stint, despite another strong Champions League showing, resulted in one of the club's worst La Liga seasons, with the team dropping to 15th by February 2003. This led to van Gaal's resignation and Radomir Antić stepping in, who could only secure a sixth-place finish. Antić's short-term contract wasn't renewed at season's end, and club president Joan Gaspart resigned, his position untenable after such a disastrous season and the club's decline since his presidency began three years earlier.
